body.p: Metadata is a broad concept that describes data the explains or identifies other data. Metadata can be used for many purposes, from driving automation of document builds to enabling authors and readers to find content more easily. DITA provides a number of types of metadata, each of which has different uses and is created in different places and in different ways. Some of the most important forms of metadata in DITA are:

section.title: Topic metadata
section.p: Topic metadata describes the topic and what it is about. Topic metadata can be inserted in the prolog element of a topic or inside the topicref element that points to a topic from a map. In other words, metadata about the topic can be asserted by the topic itself, or can be assigned to it by the map that includes it in the build. This allows different maps to assign different metadata to the same topic. This may be appropriate where you want to describe a topic differently in different documents.

section.title: Taxonomy and subject scheme
section.p: A taxonomy is a controlled vocabulary. It can be used to standardize the way in which many things in your content and metadata are named. This consistency in naming can help ensure that automated process work correctly and that consistent terminology is used in content, and in metadata. In DITA, taxonomies are created using subject scheme maps.
